markdownRemark.html:
Hey, it’s been a long time since I’ve written a blog. Here I’ll write a bit about technology, music, gaming, cities, and other personal interests. For this site, I’ve decided to try out Gatsby.js, a static site generator for React. In this post, I’ll talk about my favorite things about Gatsby so far.

Markdown

Gatsby has a variety of plugins and transformers for processing files. With the filesystem plugin and the markdown transformer, Gatsby can read a directory structure of markdown files, automatically compile them to HTML output, and create URLs for each post.

To create a new post, I simply create a new directory under “pages” and place an index.md file in it. The name of the directory becomes the URL slug, and the markdown file is re-rendered in the browser instantly when I save the file in my editor.

Syntax Highlighting

The starter blog comes with prismjs, which adds syntax highlighting for code snippets and has support for dozens of languages and themes.

I chose the Okaidia theme and imported the CSS like so:

require("prismjs/themes/prism-okaidia.css")

Here is how the syntax highlighting looks for Python, PHP, JavaScript, and Java:

Python
def hello(self):
    print "world"
    return True
PHP
<?php
function hello() {
    return "World";
}
?>
JavaScript
const hello = (hi) => {
    return "world";
}
Java
public class HelloWorld {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println("Hello, World");
    }

}

Modern JavaScript

Gatsby has a CLI that makes it easy to initialize and build a new project. It comes with Webpack and preconfigured, so you get nice features like hot reloading, ES6, and an asset pipeline. I am starting with a simple static site, but you can easily create a route to a React component that requests an API or performs other processing.

Starters and Themes

Deploy to Github Pages

No server here.

npm install gh-pages --save-dev

Then add following line in package.json

    "deploy": "gatsby build && gh-pages -d public -b master"

Then just run the deploy command with npm and all the JS, CSS, and HTML will be compiled. 

npm run deploy

There are also some neat things with GraphQL.
